[[File:The lake monster^ - geograph.org.uk - 776720.jpg|thumb|right|Tree roots exposed by water and covered in vegetation - a sight that could be misidentified as a lake monster.]]
A '''lake monster''' is a lake-dwelling entity of mythic origin. A well-known example is the [[Loch Ness Monster]]. Lake monsters' depictions are often similar to [[sea monster]]s.
== Origins ==
According to the Swedish naturalist and author Bengt Sjögren (1980), the present-day lake monsters are variations of older legends of [[kelpie|water kelpies]].{{R|"Sjögren"}} Sjögren claims that the accounts of lake-monsters have changed during history, as do others.{{R|"hill"}} Older reports often talk about horse-like appearances, but more modern reports often have more reptile and dinosaur-like appearances, he concludes that the legendary kelpies evolved into the present day [[saurian]] lake-monsters since the discovery of [[dinosaur]]s and giant aquatic reptiles and the popularization of them in both scientific and fictional writings and art.{{R|"Sjögren"}}{{R|"dinsdale"}}
The stories cut across cultures, existing in some variation in many countries.{{R|"Baraniuk"}}{{R|"meurger"}}{{R|"sharpe"}} They've undergone what Michel Meurger calls concretizing (The process of turning items, drawings, general beliefs and stories into a plausible whole) and naturalization over time as humanity's view of the world has changed.{{R|"hill"}}
In many of these areas, especially around [[Loch Ness]], [[Lake Champlain]] and the [[Okanagan Valley]], these lake monsters have become important tourist draws.
== Alternative explanations ==
In [[Ben Radford]] and [[Joe Nickell]]'s book ''Lake Monster Mysteries'',{{R|"RadfordNickell"}} the authors attribute a vast number of sightings to [[otter]] misidentifications. Ed Grabianowski plotted the distribution of North American lake monster sightings. Then he overlaid the distribution of the common otter and found a near perfect match. It turns out that three or four otters swimming in a line look remarkably like a serpentine, humped creature undulating through the water. It is very easy to mistake for a single creature if you see them from a distance. "This isn't speculation. I'm not making this up," Nickell said. "I've spoken to people who saw what they thought was a lake monster, got closer and discovered it was actually a line of otters. That really happens."{{R|"nickell2007"}} Clearly, not every lake monster sighting can be accounted for with otters, but it's an excellent example of how our perceptions can be fooled.{{R|"Grabianowski"}}
Paul Barrett and [[Darren Naish]] note that the existence of any large animals in isolation (i.e., in a situation where no breeding population exists) is highly unlikely. Naish also observes that the stories are likely remnants of tales meant to keep children safely away from the water.{{R|"Baraniuk"}}{{R|"sharpe"}}
There have been many purported sightings of lake monsters, and even some photographs, but each time these have either been shown to be deliberate deceptions, such as the Lake George Monster Hoax,{{R|"nickell2004"}} or serious doubts about the veracity and verifiability have arisen, as with the famous Mansi photograph of [[Champ (folklore)|Champ]].{{R|"bartholomew"}}
==Examples== {{main|List of lake monsters}} Well-known lake monsters include: * [[Loch Ness Monster|Nessie]], in [[Loch Ness]], Scotland * [[Morag (loch monster)|Morag]], in [[Loch Morar]], Scotland * [[Lagarfljót Worm]], in [[Lagarfljót]], Iceland * [[Ogopogo]], in [[Okanagan Lake]], Canada * [[Lariosauro]], in [[Lake Como]], Italy * [[Champ (cryptozoology)|Champ]], in [[Lake Champlain]], Canada and US * [[Memphre]], in [[Lake Memphremagog]], Canada and US * [[Bessie (lake monster)|Bessie]], in [[Lake Erie]], Canada and US * [[Nahuelito]], in [[Nahuel Huapi Lake]], Argentina * [[Monster of Lake Tota|Muyso]] or Monster of Lake Tota, in [[Lake Tota]], Colombia * [[Lake Van Monster|Van Gölü Canavarı]] or Lake Van Monster, in [[Lake Van]], Turkey * [[Inkanyamba]], in [[Howick Falls]], South Africa * [[Tahoe Tessie]], in [[Lake Tahoe]], US * [[Flathead Lake Monster]], [[Flathead Lake]], [[Montana]], US

A '''Melfan''' ([[Sector General#Sector General's physiological classification system|physiological classification]] '''ELNT''') is one of about seventy known intelligent species in the fictional [[Sector General]] universe, and one of the most common species in Sector 12 General Hospital itself. Overall, a Melfan resembles a 6-foot-long crab. Compared with most other races, they are very emotional and passionate people.<ref name="melfan">{{cite web|url=http://www.elvwood.org/Gurps/SectorGeneral/Melfans.html|title=GURPS Sector General races|date=2002|publisher=[[Steve Jackson Games]]|accessdate=22 November 2007}}</ref> They, like the majority of races in the Sector General universe, wear no clothing or body ornaments.
==Physical Summary==
===Requirements=== Melfans are amphibious, being comfortable in water or on land. They eat every ten hours, and sleep for four hours in between. Their favourite dishes include swamp nuts and live crottled greeps, although at Sector General they have to make do with moving electrically charged substitutes.<ref name="melfan"/>
===Physiology=== The Melfan head has large, vertically lidded eyes, enormous mandibles, and pincers projecting forward from the place where ears would otherwise be. There are also two long, thin, fragile, flexible feelers growing from the sides of the mouth, which feel like soft, furry feathers to the touch. When angry they click their pincers together rapidly; a slow clicking indicates a desire for attention. Projecting from slits where the bony carapace and underside join are six thin, bony, tubular, multijointed limbs, all of which are capable of manipulation but lack a sense of touch.<ref name="melfan"/> They are immobilised if they get turned onto their backs.

{{other people||Michael Breen (disambiguation)}} {{POV|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Mike Breen | image = | caption = | birth_date = 13 June 1958 | birth_place = | occupation = [[Author]], [[Public speaker|speaker]], [[pastor]] | spouse = Sally Breen | parents = | children = Beccy, Libby, Sam }}
'''Mike Breen''' (born 13 June 1958) is an English church leader, [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]], [[author]] and [[entrepreneur]]. Breen has been an innovator in leading [[missional church]]es throughout Europe and the United States.
==Biography==
===Early life=== Breen recalls never having read a book at age 16, due to [[dyslexia]]. To enable him to partake in classroom discussions, his school teacher and returned missionary, Mrs. Dearmest, handed him a ''[[Living Bible]]'' to read. He read it all and his life changed.<ref>[[#Breen2010a|Breen, Mike (2010) p. xiii]]</ref>
===Education and ministry=== Breen holds a degree from [[Cranmer Hall, Durham]], a [[Church of England]] [[theological college]] and is an ordained minister in the Church of England. He started out as a [[Curate#Anglican Communion|curate]] in [[Cambridge]] in 1984.<ref>[[#Breen2010b|Breen (2010b) p. 16]]</ref> From 1987, he served as parish priest in [[Brixton]] in the inner city of [[London]]<ref>[[#BreenKallestad2005b|Breen & Kallestad (2005b) p. 212]]</ref> — a "tough parish in the east end of London. Brixton is like south-central Los-Angeles in many ways".<ref>[[#GibbsBolger2005|Mal Calladine in Gibbs & Bolger (2005) p. 251]]</ref> During his time in Brixton, Breen pioneered [[missional community|missional communities]] as a ministry model.<ref>[[#HopkinsBreen2007|Hopkins & Breen (2007) p. 14]]</ref>
The Breen family lived in [[Little Rock]], [[Arkansas]] from 1991 to 1994.<ref>[[#HopkinsBreen2007|Hopkins & Breen (2007) p. 10]]</ref>
In 1994, Breen moved to [[Sheffield]], following [[Robert Warren (minister)|Robert Warren]] as [[Rector (ecclesiastical)#Anglican churches|senior rector]] of [[St. Thomas' Church, Crookes]],<ref>[[#HopkinsBreen2007|Hopkins & Breen (2007) p. 15]]</ref> an Anglican-Baptist local ecumenical partnership. As team leader, Breen led St Thomas' to become England's largest church by attendance by the turn of the decade.<ref>[[#Brierley2000|Brierley (2000)]]</ref>
While at St Thomas', Breen begun The Order of Mission, a Protestant, Charismatic and Evangelical monastic order. As vicar, Breen became the order's "Senior Guardian of ''The Order of Mission''" (TOM).<ref>[[#Percy2005|Percy (2005) p. 6]]</ref>
In 2004, Breen moved to [[Glendale, Arizona|Glendale]], [[Arizona]], to serve as a pastor of the Community Church of Joy and taught at [[Fuller Theological Seminary]] in [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]], [[California]].<ref>[[#BreenKallestad2005a|Breen & Kallestad (2005a) cover inside back flap]]</ref>
In 2006, the [[Leadership Network]] approached Breen to lead an initiative into church planting.<ref>[[#Breen2010a|Breen (2010), cover inside back flap]]</ref> The European Church Planting Network was established in 2007 with Breen as a senior leader. The ECPN Leadership Community gathered church leaders from all over Europe, with a stated goal of seeing 500 new churches planted across Eastern and Western Europe by the end of 2011. The result of 1,137 significantly exceeded this goal.<ref>[[#Leadnet|http://leadnet.org/page/ecpn]]</ref>
From 2008 to 2014, Breen lived at [[Pawleys Island, South Carolina]], where he serves as the leader for 3D Movements, an "organic movement of biblical discipleship and missional church"<ref>[[#BreenBlog|http://mikebreen.wordpress.com/]]</ref> helping established churches and church planters move into a discipling and missional way of being church.<ref>[[#Breen2010|Breen (2010) cover inside back flap]]</ref> 3DM decentralized in 2014, with Jo Saxton eventually becoming Chair of the Board as of June 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.josaxton.com/about-me/|title=About Me – Jo Saxton|website=www.josaxton.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> Breen moved to Greenville, South Carolina,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.3dmpublishing.com/our-story|title=Our Story|website=3DM Publishing|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> and began working on his Ph.D. at Trinity Seminary. Breen continued writing for 3DM Publishing, releasing updated editions of ''Building a Discipling Culture'' and ''Family on Mission'' (with his wife Sally), among others.
In January 2014 Breen spoke in a leadership event to the multi-thousand member North Heights Lutheran Church, which sparked concerns leading to the April, 2014 decision of the elder board to remove 3DM completely from the church, and publishing at length the reasons for their decision. Among those reasons attributed to 3DM were that, "worship attendance has dropped off dramatically," and a corresponding drop in giving.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhlc.org/about/what-we-believe/3dm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150816152311/http://www.nhlc.org/about/what-we-believe/3dm |archivedate=2015-08-16 |df= }}</ref> Other churches experienced success through 3DM partnerships, for example Billabong Uniting Church in Western Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://journeyonline.com.au/queensland-synod-news/discipleship-moves-third-dimension/|title=Discipleship moves in to the third dimension - JourneyOnline|website=journeyonline.com.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref>
===Marriage and children=== Breen is married to Sally Breen. The couple have three children, Beccy, Libby and Sam.<ref>[[#BreenBlog|http://mikebreen.wordpress.com/about/]]</ref>
==Notable contributions==
* [[Missional Communities]], also named ''clusters'' and ''MCs'' * Life Shapes * Huddles
==Published works==
Breen's books have been translated into [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[German language|German]], and [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]].

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Monroe Salisbury | image = Monroe Salisbury 1919.jpg | caption = Photo of Salisbury from ''Moving Picture World'', May 1919 | birth_date = {{birth date|1876|5|8}} | birth_place = [[Angola, New York]], US | death_date = {{death date and age|1935|8|7|1876|5|8}} | death_place = [[San Bernardino, California]], US | birthname = Orange Salisbury Cash | occupation = Actor | yearsactive = 1898–1930 }} '''Monroe Salisbury''' (May 8, 1876 – August 7, 1935) was an American actor. He appeared on the [[theatre|stage]] for several years and then became an early film star.
Salisbury was a [[matinee idol]]. He began his [[acting]] career on the stage in 1898, appearing in numerous romantic leads. He also appeared in five [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions. He was in 42 [[silent film|silent movies]] between 1914 and 1922, working frequently with director [[Cecil B. DeMille]]. Salisbury, who appeared in several [[western (genre)|western]] films, also appeared in two [[sound film|talkies]], in 1929 and 1930.
After his career was at an end, Salisbury died at a [[psychiatric hospital|mental hospital]] from a fractured skull sustained during a fall.
==Early life== He was born '''Orange Salisbury Cash''' in [[Angola, New York]],<ref>1880 Erie Co., NY, U.S. Federal Census, Evans, July 14, Enumeration Dist. 91, Sheet 18, Page 347 B, Line 33, David Cash; Line 34, Ellen Cash; Line 37, Orange Cash, White, Male, 4, Son, Single, '''NY''', NY, NY.</ref> the son of David Cash (c. 1840–?) and Ellen Louise Salisbury (1842–1929). Orr's two elder sisters were Adelaide Mary Cash (1864–1956), who married John Casper Bosche (1861–1929), and Anna Louise Cash (1868–1951), who married Edward Clarke.
His mother had a younger brother named Orange James Salisbury (1844–1907). She also had an elder brother named Monroe Salisbury (1835–1905), a government contractor and well-known [[horse racing|turfman]] who bred racehorses.
==Stage career== Orr took the name Monroe Salisbury as his stage name. He appeared behind the footlights with such notables as [[Richard Mansfield]], [[Eleonora Duse]], [[John Drew, Jr.|John Drew]], [[Nance O'Neil]], [[Mrs. Fiske|Minnie Maddern Fiske]], and [[Kathryn Kidder]].
While he was performing in [[Providence, Rhode Island]], in June 1900, Salisbury and his mother were staying in a hotel on Weybosset Street when the [[United States Census|U.S. Federal Census]] was taken.<ref>1900 Providence Co., RI, U.S. Federal Census, Providence, Ward 4, 205 Weybosset St., June 5, Enumeration Dist. 37, Sheet 2 A, Page 297 A, Line 22, O.S. Cash, Boarder, White, Male, May 1876, 24, Single, '''NY''', NY, NY, Actor, 0, Y, Y, Y; Line 23, E.L. Cash.</ref> His debut on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] was in the play ''Marta of the Lowlands'' (1903).
==Film career== [[File:Hungry Eyes 1918.jpg|thumb|''Hungry Eyes'' (1918)]] Salisbury's film debut was in the uncredited role as Sir Henry, Earl of Kerhill, in [[Cecil B. DeMille|DeMille]]'s ''[[The Squaw Man (1914 film)|The Squaw Man]]'' (1914). He also worked for DeMille in such movies as ''[[Brewster's Millions (1914 film)|Brewster's Millions]]'', ''[[The Master Mind]]'', ''[[The Virginian (1914 film)|The Virginian]]'', and ''[[Rose of the Rancho]]'', which were all released in 1914. He also appeared alongside [[Douglas Fairbanks]] in ''[[The Lamb (1915 film)|The Lamb]]'' and ''[[Double Trouble (1915 film)|Double Trouble]]'' (both [1915).
Salisbury scored his greatest success when he starred as Alessandro in ''[[Ramona (1916 film)|Ramona]]'' (1916) opposite [[Adda Gleason]] in the title role. He then signed with [[Universal Studios]], where he was among the top movie stars for several years.
When he registered for the draft of [[World War I]], in late 1918, Salisbury and his mother were living in the Mountain View Inn at 5956 [[Hollywood Boulevard]] in [[Hollywood, Los Angeles, California|Hollywood]].<ref>World War I Draft Registration Card, Serial No. 2410, Order No. 901, Name: Orange Salisbury Cash, Address: 5956 Hollywood Bl., Hwd., Los Angeles Co., Age in Years: 42, Date of Birth: May 8, 1876, Race: White, Citizenship: Native Born, Present Occupation: Actor, Employer's Name: Universal Film Co., Employer Location: Universal City, Los Angeles Co., Cal., Nearest Relative: Mrs. Ellen Louise Cash 5956 Hollywood Bl., Hwd., Los Angeles Co., Signed: Orange Salisbury Cash (signature below: Monroe Salisbury), Registrar's Report: Description of Registrant: Height: Tall, Build: Medium, Color of Eyes: Hazel, Color of Hair: Dark Brown, Any physical problems: No, Registrar Note: "Professionally known only as "Monroe Salisbury." This name used as his 15 years." Dated September 15, 1918, Local Draft Board: 14, Los Angeles, Cal.</ref>
In the late 1910s he bought a {{convert|40|acre|m2|adj=on}} citrus ranch near [[Hemet, California|Hemet]], and, between pictures, it was his habit to drive out and drop in unexpectedly on the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] overseer and his family who lived on the place and worked in the groves.<ref>''Los Angeles Times'', October 24, 1919, "Droll Stories --- No Proof There," p. II 4.</ref>
In 1920 Salisbury and his mother were still living at the Mountain View Inn on Hollywood Boulevard.<ref>1920 Los Angeles Co., CA, U.S. Federal Census, Los Angeles, Precinct 403, Mountain View Inn, 5956 Hollywood Blvd., January 9, Enumeration Dist. 169, Sheet 6 B, Page 215 B, Line 57, Monroe Salisbury, Boarder, Male, White, 42, Single, Y, Y, '''NY''', NY, NY, Y, Actor, Motion Pictures; Line 58, Ellen Louise Cash.</ref> He formed his own [[production company]], that same year, and [[filmmaking|produced]] and starred in ''[[The Barbarian (1920 film)|The Barbarian]]'' (1920). His final starring role was in the [[drama film|drama]] ''[[Great Alone]]'' (1922), in which he played a half-Native American college student and football player, a character presumably half his age. He then retired from the screen.
In June 1928, he returned to the U.S. at the Port of [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], from [[Kobe|Kobe, Japan]], aboard the S.S. Taiyo Maru, and gave his U.S. address as Hemet, California.<ref>California Passenger and Crew Lists, List of United States Citizens (For the Immigration Authorities), No. 108, S.S. Taiyo Maru, Sailing from: Kobe, Japan, June 5, 1928, Arriving at Port of San Francisco, Calif., June 22, 1928, Name in Full: Monroe Salisbury, Age: 52, Sex: Male, Married or Single: S, Date and Place of Birth: New York [sic], N.Y. May 8, 1876, Address in U.S.: Hemet, Calif.</ref>
==Comeback== With the advent of sound in the late 1920s, Salisbury returned to the screen in two talkies. He appeared in a [[Christie Film Company|Christie]] [[comedy film|comedy]] [[short subject|short]], ''[[Her Husband's Woman]]'' (1929). He then played John Lamar in Universal's 10 chapter [[serial (film)|serial]] ''[[The Jade Box]]'' (1930).
''The Jade Box'' serial was Salisbury's final movie appearances. In 1930, he was living at the Warner Kelton Hotel at 6326 Lexington Avenue, just west of Vine Street, in Hollywood,<ref>1930 Los Angeles Co., CA, U.S. Federal Census, Los Angeles, Assembly Dist. 55, Warner Kelton Hotel, 6326 Lexington Ave., April 14, Enumeration Dist. 47, Sheet 23 B, Page 157 B, Line 84, Monroe Salisbury, Head, Rented, $60, Male, White, 49 [sic], Single, N, Y, '''NY''', NY, NY, Y, Actor, Theatrical, Wages, Y, (Vet.?) N.</ref> later called the ''Hotel Brevoort (and Tropical Gardens)''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/6326+Lexington+Ave,+Los+Angeles,+CA+90038/@34.0923165,-118.3274688,93a,35y,180h/data=!3m1!1e3!4m5!3m4!1s0x80c2bf341741d81d:0x2802da3652cdad39!8m2!3d34.0923922!4d-118.3276112?hl=en|title=6326 Lexington Ave|author=|date=|website=google.com/maps|accessdate=August 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801102646/http://allanellenberger.com/elizabeth-shorts-hollywood/|title=HOLLYWOODLAND » Elizabeth Short’s Hollywood…|author=Allan Ellenberger|date=July 29, 2008|archivedate=August 1, 2013|website=allanellenberger.com|via=archive.org|accessdate=August 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130731010854/https://martinturnbull.com/hollywood-places/|title=Hollywood Places|author=Martin Turnbull|date=July 31, 2013|website=martinturnbull.com|via=archive.org|accessdate=August 15, 2018}}</ref>
In February 1932, he returned to [[Southern California]], at [[San Pedro, Los Angeles, California|San Pedro]], from [[Ensenada, Baja California|Ensenada, Mexico]], aboard the S.S. Ruth Alexander, and gave his U.S. address as 6326 Lexington Hollywood.<ref>California Passenger and Crew Lists, List of United States Citizens (For the Immigration Authorities), No. 1562, S.S. Ruth Alexander, Sailing from: Ensenada, Mexico, February 28, 1932, Arriving at Port of San Pedro, Calif., February 28, 1932, Name in Full: Monroe Salisbury, Age: 55, Sex: Male, Married or Single: M, Date and Place of Birth: Buffalo [sic], N.Y. May 8, 1877 [sic], Address in U.S.: 6326 Lexington Hollywood.</ref>
==Final years== On July 2, 1935, Salisbury entered [[Patton State Hospital]], a [[psychiatric hospital|mental facility]] near [[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]], as a patient. He may have been admitted under his real name, Orr Cash. His occupation was given as hotel clerk. A month later, he suffered a bad fall at the institution and was fatally injured.
Monroe Salisbury died at age 59 from a fractured skull sustained in his fall at the institution.<ref>''Los Angeles Times'', August 9, 1935, "End Tragic --- Ex-Film Idol Dies In Fall --- Body of Monroe Salisbury, Long Unidentified, Held in San Bernardino," p. 1.</ref><ref>''New York Times'', August 9, 1935, from San Bernardino, Calif., Aug 8, "Monroe Salisbury --- Former Star of Films, 59, Was Injured Fatally in Fall," p. 17.</ref> He was at a local mortuary for a day before his true identity was discovered. Only four mourners were present at his funeral on August 9, 1935, at the mortuary in San Bernardino.<ref>''Los Angeles Times'', August 10, 1935, "Four Attend Last Rites For Salisbury, Ex-Actor," p. A 1.</ref> His body was returned to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], for [[cremation]] and his ashes interred with his mother in the family plot at [[Angelus-Rosedale Cemetery|Rosedale Cemetery]].<ref>Angelus-Rosedale Cemetery, Los Angeles, California, Sexton Records, Orr S. Cash.</ref>

{{Use Australian English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox news event |name = Murder of Tiahleigh Palmer |image = Tiahleigh Palmer family carrying coffin.jpg |caption = Palmer's friends and family carry her coffin at her funeral. Her killer, Rick Thorburn, is the second pallbearer from the left. |alt = A group of six people dressed in purple carry a white coffin from concrete onto a footpath, next to a woman in a white shirt holding a bouquet of flowers. |date = Murdered 30 October 2015
Remains found 5 November 2015
Remains identified 6 November 2015 |place = [[City of Logan|Logan]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] }} {{Infobox person |image = Tiahleigh Palmer ABC 1.jpg |caption = Palmer in her school uniform |alt = A girl in a school uniform wearing a purple backpack stands in front of a house. |name = Tiahleigh Palmer |birth_name = Tiahleigh Alyssa Rose Palmer |birth_date = {{Birth date based on age at death|12|2015}} |death_place = [[Chambers Flat, Queensland|Chambers Flat]] |death_date = 30 October 2015 (aged 12) |body_discovered = Kerkin Road North [[Pimpama River]] }} '''Tiahleigh Alyssa Rose Palmer''' (sometimes known as '''Tia''' or '''Tiah''') was a 12-year-old Australian girl who lived in [[Logan City|Logan City, Queensland]].{{Cite web|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]|title=Tiahleigh Palmer: Police say those involved in 12yo's death 'should not feel comfortable'|date=18 November 2015|accessdate=22 December 2015|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-18/detective-tells-tiahleigh-palmer's-killer-not-to-get-comfortable/6952378}} She was murdered on 30 October 2015. Her remains were found six days later and her foster father, Rick Thorburn, was charged on 20 September 2016 with her murder. Thorburn pleaded guilty to the murder before the [[Supreme Court of Queensland]] on 25 May 2018.{{cite web|last1=Horn|first1=Allyson|last2=Silva|first2=Kristian|title=Tiahleigh Palmer's killer foster father Rick Thorburn played 'role of concerned parent'|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-05-25/court-tiahleigh-palmer-murder-rick-thorburn-sentencing/9791556|website=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=25 May 2018|date=25 May 2018}} ==Disappearance and death== Palmer's foster father says he drove her to [[Marsden State High School]] on 30 October 2015, dropping her off at about 8:10am.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3308020/Mother-Tiahleigh-Palmer-12-decomposed-body-river-suspicious-circumstances-trying-overcome-criminal-past-regain-custody.html|title=EXCLUSIVE: Mother of Tiahleigh Palmer, 12, whose body was found in a river, was 'trying to overcome criminal past and regain custody'... as police search for her school uniform and backpack|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|last=Thackray|first=Lucy|date=7 November 2015|accessdate=22 December 2015}} She did not attend any classes and was not seen for the rest of the day. On 5 November, police released photos and appealed to the public for information on her whereabouts in a press conference.{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/crime/police-handling-of-the-tiahleigh-palmer-case-under-scrutiny/news-story/56d20a7be442e3a05a6206f3db0c9915|publisher=[[News.com.au]]|title=Police handling of the Tiahleigh Palmer case under scrutiny|date=12 November 2015|last=Koubaridis|first=Andrew|accessdate=22 December 2015}} Later that day, the remains of a female aged 12–18 were found on the bank of the [[Pimpama River]] and, on 6 November, they were officially identified as Palmer's. Police then began a search for her backpack and school uniform.{{Cite web|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]|title=Timeline: The discovery of Tiahleigh Palmer's body and investigation into her suspected murder|date=7 December 2015|accessdate=22 December 2015|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-13/timeline-on-tiahleigh-palmer-suspected-murder/6926556}} On 7 November, a vigil was held in Logan and, on 14 November, her funeral was held and attended by more than 600 people.{{Cite web|publisher=''[[Brisbane Times]]''|title=Tiahleigh Palmer: Crowds gather for 12-year-old's funeral in Logan|last=Silva|first=Kristian|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/tiahleigh-palmer-crowds-gather-for-12yearolds-funeral-in-logan-20151113-gkywcq.html|date=14 November 2015|accessdate=22 December 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Burke|first1=Liz|title=The foster father charged over Tiahleigh Palmer's murder|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/the-foster-father-charged-over-tiahleigh-palmers-murder/news-story/c1359f1eb41eeef07cadb6fdc1b06501|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=Herald Sun|date=23 September 2016}} On 4 December 2015, a shoe believed to be Palmer's was found near where her body was discovered.{{Cite web |publisher=''[[Sky News Australia]]'' |date=5 December 2015 |accessdate=22 December 2015 |url=http://www.skynews.com.au/news/top-stories/2015/12/05/muddy-shoe-found-in-tiahleigh-palmer-case.html |title=Muddy shoe found in Tiahleigh Palmer case |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151205124902/http://www.skynews.com.au/news/top-stories/2015/12/05/muddy-shoe-found-in-tiahleigh-palmer-case.html |archivedate=5 December 2015 |df=dmy }} Police conducted many interviews, searched the area around the Pimpama River and forensically examined a number of houses and vehicles. The investigation failed to find her missing backpack and school uniform.{{cite news|url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2016/03/23/15/36/tiahleigh-palmer-logan-house-searched-in-murdered-schoolgirl-case|title=Tiahleigh Palmer: Detectives continue to examine Logan house in murdered schoolgirl case|date=24 March 2016|work=9 News Australia|accessdate=24 March 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.msn.com/en-au/news/australia/tiahleigh-palmer-detectives-continue-to-examine-logan-house-in-murdered-schoolgirl-case/ar-BBqOdYr?ocid=spartanntp|title=Tiahleigh Palmer: Detectives continue to examine Logan house in murdered schoolgirl case|date=24 March 2016|work=MSN Australia|accessdate=24 March 2016}} ==Criminal proceedings== Palmer's foster father, Rick Thorburn, was a person of interest to police from the earliest days of the investigation. The Thorburns fostered no more children after Palmer's disappearance, but continued to run a daycare service from their home until April 2016 when the state's education and child safety departments were advised by police that Rick Thorburn was facing nine serious charges unrelated to Palmer, and the family's daycare approval was revoked and their foster care approval was suspended.{{cite web|work=The Weekend Australian|date=22 September 2016|accessdate=16 April 2017|author=Geoff Chambers|title=Rick Thorburn kept foster care licence|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/state-politics/rick-thorburn-kept-foster-care-licence/news-story/b2b6260d8d2c0dc319cdc665450e0bc1}} In September 2016 a car formerly owned by Rick Thorburn was seized by police for forensic examination and, on 20 September 2016, Palmer's foster parents and their two sons were taken into police custody for questioning. Rick Thorburn was charged with Palmer's murder and with interfering with a corpse. He collapsed shortly after his arrest and was subsequently placed in an induced coma for several days, missing a scheduled court appearance the next day. Police are looking into whether he took pills just before or after his arrest, in a suicide attempt.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-22/tiahleigh-palmer-foster-father-coma-pills-ethical-standards/7867046|title=Ethical standards investigate collapse of Tia's accused killer|date=21 September 2016|work=abc.net.au|accessdate=22 September 2016}} Palmer's 19-year-old foster brother, Trent, was charged with two counts of perjury and one count each of attempting to pervert the course of justice and incest, and was denied bail.{{cite web|title=Tiahleigh Palmer death: Foster father Rick Thorburn charged with murder|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-20/tiahleigh-palmer-foster-father-charged-with-murder/7860530|website=ABC News|accessdate=20 September 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Branco|first1=Jorge|title=Tiahleigh Palmer murder investigation: Foster father charged with murder|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/tiahleigh-palmer-murder-investigation-foster-father-to-be-charged-with-murder-20160920-grk4zc.html|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=Brisbane Times|date=20 September 2016}} Her foster mother, Julene, and older foster brother, Joshua, were both charged with perjury and attempting to pervert the course of justice and released on bail. Palmer's grandmother has told reporters that, months before she died, Palmer had declined an option to move in with her mother because she had a crush on Trent, and because she loved the horses on the Thorburn property. In a court hearing on 21 September 2016 prosecutors said that, two days before her death, Trent confessed to a cousin that he had had sex with Palmer on the previous Monday, and that she had told his mother about it.{{cite news|last1=Branco|first1=Jorge|title=Tiahleigh Palmer's foster brother 'told cousin he had sex with her', court hears|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/tiahleigh-palmers-foster-father-in-coma-wont-appear-in-court-20160921-grkwvf.html|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=Brisbane times|date=21 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Liz|title=Toxic relationship between murdered Tiahleigh Palmer and brother revealed|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/queensland/crime/toxic-relationship-between-murdered-tiahleigh-palmer-and-brother-revealed/news-story/d6275a57ca4d7149cdb3fdd566375147|website=News.com.au|accessdate=22 September 2016}} The court also heard that, shortly before her death, Palmer had told a friend that Trent would have sex with her when Mrs Thorburn went out, and she had told her foster mother about the abuse. Prosecutors say that Trent now admits he was lying when he had earlier repeatedly denied the abuse to his parents and police.{{cite news|last1=Beers|first1=Lucy Mae|last2=Geary|first2=Belinda Grant|last3=Crane|first3=Emily|title=Tiahleigh Palmer's grandmother said the 'schoolgirl could have left the incestuous relationship with her foster brother - but chose to stay because she had a crush on him|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3801318/Tiahleigh-Palmer-s-grandma-claims-child-crush-Trent-Thorburn.html|accessdate=22 September 2016|work=Daily Mail Australia|date=24 September 2016}} On 23 September 2016, investigators began excavating the Thorburns' rural property in a search for evidence.{{cite news|title=Tiahleigh Palmer: Police excavate home of accused murderer, foster father Rick Thorburn|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-23/tiahleigh-palmer-police-excavate-rural-property-thorburn/7870584|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=ABC News|date=23 September 2016}} Rick Thorburn said nothing to investigators, but Julene and Joshua both made statements to police.{{cite news|last1=Stephens|first1=Kim|title=Little girl lost: On the trail of Tiahleigh Palmer's killer|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/queensland/crime/little-girl-lost-on-the-trail-of-tiahleigh-palmers-killer/news-story/ff2d1805c743f1d1cf99d8ef6fec8d83|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=News.com.au|date=24 September 2016}} On 10 October, Julene's and Joshua's lawyer told a court they would plead guilty to all charges and had agreed to be witnesses for the prosecution.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-10/tiahleigh-palmer-foster-mother-brother-to-plead-guilty-perjury/7918490 Tiahleigh Palmer: Former foster mother, brother to plead guilty to perjury over 12yo schoolgirl's death], [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]], 10 October 2016{{cite news|last1=Schaefer|first1=Timothy|title=Tiahleigh Palmer's foster family turn on accused killer father|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/tiahleigh-palmers-foster-mum-to-plead-guilty-20161010-gryp1r.html|accessdate=11 October 2016|work=Brisbane Times|date=10 October 2016}} In March 2018 it was reported that Rick Thorburn intended to plead guilty to Palmer's murder,{{cite web|title=Tiahleigh Palmer death: Rick Thorburn to plead guilty to murder, lawyer says|url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/real-life/news-life/tiahleigh-palmer-death-rick-thorburn-to-plead-guilty-to-murder-lawyer-says/news-story/cd3db358f9b5aecf3a7db02643f6ba0d|website=news.com.au|accessdate=19 March 2018|date=19 March 2018}} and he did so formally before the Supreme Court on 25 May 2018. He was then sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole for at least 20 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-05-25/court-tiahleigh-palmer-murder-rick-thorburn-life-sentence-jail/9791556|title=Tiahleigh Palmer's foster father jailed for life for 'callous' murder and cover-up|date=25 May 2018|website=abc.net.au|accessdate=26 May 2018}} In July 2017, Joshua Thorburn was sentenced to three months in jail for lying to police and hiding information about Palmer's death.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-07-27/tiahleighs-foster-brother-jailed-over-death-cover-up/8749020|title=Tiahleigh's foster brother jailed for lies after pact at secret family meeting|date=27 July 2017|website=abc.net.au|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Trent Thorburn was sentenced to four years in jail for incest, perjury and attempting to pervert the course of justice in September 2017{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-09-14/tiahleigh-palmers-foster-brother-sentenced-incest-perjury/8944526|title=Tiahleigh Palmer's foster brother gets four years' jail for incest, perjury|date=14 September 2017|website=abc.net.au|accessdate=3 November 2017}} and released on 19 January 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/queensland/foster-brother-jailed-for-incest-with-slain-schoolgirl-released-from-jail-20180119-p4yymx.html|title=Foster brother jailed for incest with slain schoolgirl is released|date=19 January 2018|publisher=|via=The Sydney Morning Herald}} In November 2017, Julene Thorburn was sentenced to 18 months in jail for perjury and attempting to pervert the course of justice.{{cite news|last1=Petrinec|first1=Melanie|title=Tiahleigh Palmer’s foster mother pleads guilty to perjury, attempting to pervert course of justice charges|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/queensland/tiahleigh-palmers-foster-mother-pleads-guilty-to-perjury-attempting-to-pervert-course-of-justice-charges/news-story/3dfff6930a1d96c916268eb25604e1c4|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=news.com.au|date=3 November 2017}} ==See also== * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{portal bar|Crime|Death|Queensland}} {{Infobox book | name = ''Packing for Mars: The Curious Science of Life in the Void'' | image = PACKING FOR MARS paperback cover.jpeg | author = [[Mary Roach]] | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Science]], [[Interplanetary space travel|Space Travel]] | genre = [[Non-Fiction]] | publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]] | release_date = 2010 | pages = 334 | isbn = 978-0-393-06847-4 }}
'''''Packing for Mars: The Curious Science of Life in the Void''''' is a non-fiction work by science author [[Mary Roach]].
Published in August 2010, ''Packing for Mars'' was recognized in "Amazon's Best Books" of that month, it quickly became a #6 ''New York Times'' bestseller,<ref>{{Cite news | title = Best Sellers: Hardcover Nonfiction | work = | publisher = The New York Times | date = 22 August 2010 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2010-08-22/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html | accessdate = 16 March 2011 | first=Jennifer | last=Schuessler}}</ref> and it was chosen as the book of the year for the 7th annual [[One City One Book]]: San Francisco Reads literary event program.<ref>{{cite web|title=One City One Book 2011|url=http://sfpl.org/index.php?pg=2000255701|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=San Francisco Public Library|year=2011}}</ref>
In ''Packing for Mars'', Mary [[Mary Roach|Roach]] searches for answers to questions about the gross, the bizarre, and the uncomfortable aspects of space travel. The book's 16 chapters cover the entire comedic spectrum of all things space-related, and also include some study of the scientific side of space travel.<ref>http://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/non-fiction/mary-roach/packing-for-mars/</ref> The chapters discussing the various bodily functions of astronauts in space (going to the bathroom, having sex, vomiting<ref name=MaryRoachUSAToday>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/reviews/2010-08-17-roachrev17_ST_N.htm | work=USA Today | first=Craig | last=Wilson | title=Packing for Mars'? Mary Roach gives us the inside 'escapee | date=16 August 2010}}</ref>) and obscure testing procedures (animals in space, lying in beds for months, parabolic zero-g<ref name=RoachInterview2>{{cite web|last=Cox|first=Tony|title='Packing for Mars' and the Weightless Life|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=128933361/|publisher=npr|accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref>) are balanced by the informative sections on topics such as the psychological effects of being in space, astronaut training, and the increasing use of human cadavers over crash test dummies in research.
==Mary Roach's overview== Mary Roach, the author of ''Packing for Mars'', was raised in Etna, New Hampshire and spent several years working as a freelance copy editor and investigating unpopular topics.<ref name=MaryRoachSite>{{cite web|last=Roach|first=Mary|title=Mary Roach|url=http://www.maryroach.net/maryroach.html|accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> Roach explores lots of questions such as what happens after we die, what sex is all about, and what secrets human cadavers hold. However, in ''Packing for Mars'', she turns her mind toward space and examines the logistics of space travel.<ref name=MaryRoachUSAToday /> In an interview, she describes her book to be about all the surreal physical and physiological challenges of living in space as a human being. Roach explains that in addition to these problems, human beings are not in the slightest equipped or prepared to confront these challenges. Although most of her other books have one-word titles, Mary Roach claims that it was especially difficult to come up with a one-word title for this specific book.<ref name=RoachInterview>{{cite web|last=Adams, Kirtley|first=John, David|title=Interview: Mary Roach|url=http://www.lightspeedmagazine.com/nonfiction/feature-interview-mary-roach/|publisher=Light Speed Magazine|accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref>
==Topics covered== The book covers 12 topics:
* The psychological specifications for being considered for a space mission * The psychological effects of being in space * Initial precautions of going to space * Testing procedures * Cadavers used for anatomically precise testing * Animal testing * Simulation procedures * Space hygiene * The physiological effects of being in space * Sex in space * Preparing food for space * The author's thoughts on space travel
== Reviews == * {{Cite news | last = Lord | first = M. G. | title = Astral Bodies | work = Sunday Book Review | publisher = The New York Times | date = 6 August 2010 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/08/books/review/Lord-t.html | accessdate = 16 March 2011}} * {{Cite web | last = | first = | title = Packing for Mars | work = Kirkus Book Reviews | publisher = Kirkus Reviews | date = 15 June 2010 | url = http://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/non-fiction/mary-roach/packing-for-mars/ | accessdate = 16 March 2011}} * {{Cite news | last = Wilson | first = Craig | title = 'Packing for Mars'? Mary Roach gives us the inside 'escapee' | work = United States Today | publisher = United States Today | date = 16 August 2010| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/reviews/2010-08-17-roachrev17_ST_N.htm | accessdate = 16 March 2011}} * [https://www.amazon.com/dp/product-description/0393068471 Amazon.com]

Norton & Company's website] * [http://fora.tv/2010/08/19/Mary_Roach_Packing_for_Mars FORA TV Interview with Mary Roach] * [http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/mon-august-2-2010/mary-roach/ Roach talks about Packing for Mars on] ''[[The Daily Show]]'' * [http://www.commonwealthclub.org/events/archive/video/mary-roach-journey-through-outer-space-without-leaving-earth-81910 Mary Roach: Journey Through Outer Space Without Leaving Earth"] * [http://sfpl.org/index.php?pg=2000484801 Roach is interviewed by] [[Adam Savage]] for [[One City One Book]] Event * [http://www.skepticality.com/packing-for-mars/ Packing for Mars interview on] [[Skepticality]] *{{cite web|title=Book Discussion on ''Packing for Mars''|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?293851-1/book-discussion-packing-mars|publisher=[[C-SPAN]]|accessdate=18 April 2015|date=27 May 2010|quote=Mary Roach recounts her field research and what it requires to travel in space in her forthcoming book, ''Packing For Mars: The Curious Science of Life in the Void''. Mary Roach was interviewed at the annual book publishing trade show, Book Expo America, held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City.}}

{{Infobox medical condition | Name = Placental disease | Image = Chorangioma - intermed mag.jpg | Caption = [[Micrograph]] of a [[chorangioma]]. [[H&E stain]]. | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|O|43||o|30}}-{{ICD10|O|45||o|30}}, {{ICD10|O|73||o|60}}, {{ICD10|P|02|0|p|00}}-{{ICD10|P|02|2|p|00}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|641.0}}-{{ICD9|641.2}}, {{ICD9|667}}, {{ICD9|762.0}}-{{ICD9|762.2}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D010922 }} Ischemic placental disease leads to the attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall to become under-perfused, causing uteroplacental ischemia. Where the term overarches the pathology associated with preeclampsia, placental abruptions and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).<ref name="pmid 24836824">{{cite journal |vauthors= Parker S, Werler M |year=2014 |title= Epidemiology of ischemic placental disease: A focus on preterm gestations. |journal=Seminars in Perinatology |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=133–138 |pmid=24836824 |pmc=4824536 |doi=10.1053/j.semperi.2014.03.004 |url=}}</ref> These factors are known to be the primary pathophysiology cause placental disease. Which is considered to be associated with more than half of premature births.<ref name="pmid18280875 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ananth C, Vintzileos A |year=2008 |title=Medically Indicated Preterm Birth: Recognizing the Importance of the Problem |journal=Clin Perinatol |volume=35 |issue=1 |pages=53–67 |pmid=18280875 |doi=10.1016/j.clp.2007.11.001 |url=}}</ref>
Abnormalities present within the spiral arteries lead to higher velocities in blood, in turn causes the maternal villi to shred.<ref name="pmid24836825">{{cite journal |vauthors= Roberts J |year=2014 |title= Pathophysiology of ischemic placental disease |journal=Seminars in Perinatology |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=139–145 |pmid=24836825 |pmc=4040272 |doi=10.1053/j.semperi.2014.03.005 |url=}}</ref> Which trigger pro-coagulator molecules to be released into the blood stream causing action of the coagulator cascade, eventually leading to placental infarction.<ref name="pmid24836825"/> Risk factors such as diabetes, chronic blood pressure and multiple pregnancies can increase the risk of developing placental disease.<ref name="pmid 24836824"/> Also, exposure to sudden trauma can increase the risk of placental abruption which coincides with placental disease.<ref name="pmid24836826 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Adam T, Yeh C, Bennett-Kunzier N, Kinzler W |year=2014 |title= Long-term maternal morbidity and mortality associated with ischemic placental disease |journal=Seminars in Perinatology |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=146–150 |pmid=24836826 |doi= 10.1053/j.semperi.2014.03.003 |url=}}</ref>
There is no target treatment available for placental disease. Associative prevention mechanisms can be a method of minimising the risk of developing the disease, within early stages of pregnancy.
==Pathophysiology==
===Signs and symptoms===
The abnormal spiral arteries lead decreased level of oxygen diffusion through the placental villus,<ref name="pmid24836825"/> which cause chronic hypoxia. The abnormal trophoblast invasion,<ref name="pmid24836825"/> lead to overall uteroplacental insufficiencies and uteroplacental underperfusion. It is due to the decreased vascularisation, there are reduced levels of nutrient delivery to the foetus.<ref name="pmid15058904">{{cite journal |vauthors=Baschat A, Hechert K |year=2004 |title=Fetal Growth Restriction due to Placental Disease |journal=Seminars in Perinatology |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=67–80 |pmid=15058904|doi= |url=}}</ref> Also, cases of still births can be associated with placental disease.<ref name="pmid19782960 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Verspyck E, Borg J, Roman H, Thobois B, Pia P, Marpeau L |year=2010 |title=Hereditary thrombophilia and recurrence of ischemic placental disease |journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology |volume=2002 |issue=1 |pages=54e1 - 54e5 |pmid=19782960 |doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2009.08.019 |url=}}</ref>
===Causes=== Preeclampsia is considered to be linked with Placental Disease, as well as intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and placental abruptions are risk factors that lead to placental disease.<ref name="pmid21839575">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ananth C, Vintzileos A |year=2011 |title=Ischemic placental disease: epidemiology and risk factors |journal=European Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Reproductive Biology |volume=159 |issue=1 |pages=77–82 |doi= 10.1016/j.ejogrb.2011.07.025 |pmid=21839575}}</ref> Especially when these symptoms are evident at early stages of pregnancy.<ref name="pmid 24836824"/> The abnormal invasion of the trophoblast cells, lack of important growth factors such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and placental growth factor (PlGF), has an association with the onset of placental disease.<ref name="pmid24836830 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Friedman A, Cleary K |year=2014 |title= Prediction and prevention of ischemic placental disease |journal=Seminars in Perinatology |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=177–182 |pmid=24836830 |doi=10.1053/j.semperi.2014.03.002 |url=}}</ref>
===Mechanism<ref name="pmid24836825"/>=== In placental disease, there’s abnormalities present within the spiral arties of the uterus, where the terminal part of the spinal arteries does not dilate. This leads to decrease oxygen carried past the maternal villi into the intervillus space. The lack of terminal dilation and inclining blood velocity causes shredding of the villi into the maternal blood, releasing blood coagulants activating the coagulation cascade. Which then leads to blocking of the blood vessels causing placental infarction.
===Risk Factors === Risk factors associated with placental disease are as follows:<ref name="pmid 24836824"/>
* Smoking cigarettes and use other forms of drugs such as cocaine. * Diabetes mellitus * Maternal age less than 20 years or over the age of 35 * Multiple pregnancies * Chronic high blood pressure * Being underweight or obese
Also, chronic renal disease, collagen vascular disease and thrombophilia, increases the risk of developing placental disease.<ref name="pmid15058904"/> Moreover, being exposed to severe trauma within the pregnancy period, rapid acceleration and deceleration and uterine compression increase the risk of placental abruption, in turn leading to placental disease.<ref name="pmid24836826 "/>
===Diagnosis<ref name="pmid15058904"/>=== Placental Disease can be diagnosed through technologies such as, Prenatal ultrasound evaluation and invasive foetal testing. The size of the foetus is taken into account through ultrasonography in terms of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). In conjunction with taking into account the maternal history.
===Treatment=== Treatment of placental disease would require a premature birth, in order to avoid a still birth.
===Epidemiology=== Placental disease is more common in preterm gestation than with full term.<ref name="pmid21839575"/> Which leads to serious injuries to both the mother and the new-born.<ref name="pmid24836830 "/> Women who endured placental disease within the first pregnancy has an increased risk of the disease progressing within future pregnancies.<ref name="pmid17601907 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ananth C, Peltier M, Chavez M, Kirby R, Getahun D, Vintzileos A |year=2017 |title=Recurrence of Ischemic Placental Disease |journal= American College of Obstetricians and gynaecologists |volume=110 |issue=1 |pages=128–133 |pmid=17601907 |doi=10.1097/01.AOG.0000266983.77458.71 |url=}}</ref> The onset of the disease within the first trimester leads to preterm delivery of a premature baby.<ref name="pmid24836828 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Vintzileos A, Ananth, C |year=2014 |title=First trimester prediction of ischemic placental disease |journal=Seminars in Perinatology |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=159–166 |pmid=24836828 |doi=10.1053/j.semperi.2014.03.006 |url=}}</ref> Preeclampsia is diagnosed in 3-5% of pregnancies that place them at risk of developing placental disease.<ref name="pmid24836826 "/> Ischemic placental disease is linked with approximately more than half of premature births.<ref name="pmid18280875 "/>
===Prevention<ref name="pmid24836830 "/>=== The following factors can be linked with reducing the likelihood of developing placental disease: *Use of aspirin, can reduce the risks associated with preeclampsia *Low calcium intake can reduce the risk of preeclampsia *Reducing oxidative stress present within the body *Intake of prenatal multivitamins
A '''placental disease''' is any disease, disorder, or pathology of the [[placenta]]. The article also covers placentation abnormalities, which is often used synonymously for placental disease.<ref name="pmid19337544">{{cite journal |vauthors=Furuya M, Ishida J, Aoki I, Fukamizu A |title=Pathophysiology of placentation abnormalities in pregnancy-induced hypertension |journal=Vasc Health Risk Manag |volume=4 |issue=6 |pages=1301–13 |year=2008 |pmid=19337544 |pmc=2663465 |doi= |url=}}</ref><ref name="pmid19099348">{{cite journal |vauthors=Cheng MH, Wang PH |title=Placentation abnormalities in the pathophysiology of preeclampsia |journal=Expert Rev. Mol. Diagn. |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=37–49 |date=January 2009 |pmid=19099348 |doi=10.1586/14737159.9.1.37 |url=}}</ref>
==Pathology==
===Adherence/penetration=== * [[Abruptio placentae]] * [[Placenta accreta]] * [[Placenta increta]] * [[Placenta percreta]]
===Inflammatory/infectious=== * [[Chorioamnionitis]] * [[Villitis of unknown etiology]] * [[Intervillitis]] * [[TORCH infections]] ** [[CMV placentitis]] * [[Chronic deciduitis]]
===Placental development=== * [[Circumvallate placenta]] * [[Placental villous immaturity]]
===Obstruction of os=== * [[Placenta previa]] * [[Vasa previa]]
===Vascular=== * [[Fetal thrombotic vasculopathy]] * [[Hypertrophic decidual vasculopathy]] * [[Chorangiosis]] * [[Chorangioma]] * [[Placental infarction]]
===Neoplastic=== Trophoblastic neoplasms derive from trophoblastic tissue. Examples include: *[[Choriocarcinoma]] *[[Hydatidiform mole]]

'''Polaris Partners''' is an investment firm that has partnered with entrepreneurs in the fields of healthcare and technology. The firm has partnered with enterprises in various stages of development.
Polaris has offices in Boston, Massachusetts and San Francisco, California. The firm has over $4 billion under management and has invested in more than 250 companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Polaris Partners Portfolio|url=http://www.polarispartners.com/portfolio/}}</ref>
==History== Polaris Partners was founded in 1995/1996 by [[Jon Flint]], [[Terry McGuire]], [[Steve Arnold (Venture Capitalist)|Steve Arnold]], who were partners of [[Burr, Egan, Deleage & Co.]] (BEDCO).
{{history of private equity and venture capital}} Polaris was the first of four successors to [[Burr, Egan, Deleage & Co.]] (BEDCO), one of the earliest bi-coastal venture capital firms in the US, which dissolved in 1996. The firm has roughly $4.0 billion under management, and is now making investments through its seventh fund.

{{For|other forms of egoism|Egoism}} {{Individualism sidebar}} '''Rational egoism''' (also called '''rational selfishness''') is the principle that an action is rational if and only if it maximizes one's self-interest.<ref name="auto">Baier (1990), p. 201; Gert (1998), p. 69; Shaver (2002), §3; Moseley (2006), §2.</ref> The view is a [[Norm (philosophy)|normative]] form of [[wikt:egoism|egoism]]. It is distinct from [[psychological egoism]] (according to which people are ''motivated'' only to act in their own self-interest) and [[ethical egoism]] (that moral agents ''ought'' only to do what is in their own self-interest).<ref name="auto"/>
== Philosophy == Rational egoism was embodied by Russian author [[Nikolay Chernyshevsky]] in the 1863 book ''[[What Is to Be Done? (novel)|What Is to Be Done?]]''.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Andrzej Walicki|author2=Hilda Andrews-Rusiecka|title=A History of Russian Thought: From the Enlightenment to Marxism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ev4ad5wKI9oC&pg=PA196|year=1979|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-1132-6|pages=196}}</ref> Chernyshevsky's standpoint was ultimately socialistic, and was criticised by [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]] in the 1864 book ''[[Notes from Underground]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Case against Rational Egoism in Dostoevsky's Notes from Underground |author=James P. Scanlan |journal=Journal of the History of Ideas |volume=60 |issue=3 |date=July 1999 |pages=549–67 |doi=10.1353/jhi.1999.0028}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sparknotes.com/lit/underground/context.html |title=SparkNotes: Notes from Underground: Context |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=[[SparkNotes]] |publisher= |access-date=2015-05-30 |quote=}}</ref>
English philosopher [[Henry Sidgwick]] discussed rational egoism in his book ''[[The Methods of Ethics]]'', first published in 1872.<ref>Sidgwick (1907)</ref> A method of ethics is "any rational procedure by which we determine what individual human beings 'ought' – or what it is 'right' for them – to do, or seek to realize by voluntary action".<ref>Sidgwick (1907), p. 1</ref> Sidgwick considers three such procedures, namely, rational egoism, dogmatic intuitionism, and [[utilitarianism]]. Rational egoism is the view that, if rational, "an agent regards quantity of consequent pleasure and pain to himself alone important in choosing between alternatives of action; and seeks always the greatest attainable surplus of pleasure over pain".<ref>Sidgwick (1907), p. 95</ref>
Sidgwick found it difficult to find any persuasive reason for preferring rational egoism over [[utilitarianism]]. Although utilitarianism can be provided with a rational basis and reconciled with the morality of common sense, rational egoism appears to be an equally plausible doctrine regarding what we have most reason to do. Thus we must "admit an ultimate and fundamental contradiction in our apparent intuitions of what is Reasonable in conduct; and from this admission it would seem to follow that the apparently intuitive operation of Practical Reason, manifested in these contradictory judgments, is after all illusory".<ref>Sidgwick (1907), p. 508</ref>
== Ayn Rand == The author and philosopher [[Ayn Rand]] also discusses a theory that she called 'rational egoism'. She holds that it is both irrational and immoral to act against one's self-interest.<ref>Smith (2006); Moseley (2006), §2a.</ref> Thus, her view is a conjunction of both rational egoism (in the standard sense) and [[ethical egoism]], because according to [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivist philosophy]], egoism cannot be properly justified without an [[epistemology]] based on [[rationality|reason]]:
Her book ''[[The Virtue of Selfishness]]'' (1964) explains the concept of rational egoism in depth. According to Rand, a rational man holds his own life as his highest value, rationality as his highest [[virtue]], and his happiness as the final purpose of his life.
Conversely, Rand was sharply critical of the [[ethical altruism|ethical doctrine of altruism]]:
{{quote|Do not confuse altruism with kindness, good will or respect for the rights of others. These are not primaries, but consequences, which, in fact, altruism makes impossible. The irreducible primary of altruism, the basic absolute is ''self-sacrifice'' – which means self-immolation, self-abnegation, self-denial self-destruction – which means the ''self'' as a standard of evil, the ''selfless'' as a standard of the good. Do not hide behind such superficialities as whether you should or should not give a dime to a beggar. This is not the issue. The issue is whether you ''do'' or do ''not'' have the right to exist ''without'' giving him that dime. The issue is whether you must keep buying your life, dime by dime, from any beggar who might choose to approach you. The issue is whether the need of others is the first mortgage on your life and the moral purpose of your existence. The issue is whether man is to be regarded as a sacrificial animal. Any man of self-esteem will answer: ''No.'' Altruism says: ''Yes.''"<ref>Ayn Rand, "Faith and Force: Destroyers of the Modern World," ''Philosophy: Who Needs it'', 1982, New American Library, p. 74.</ref>}}
==Criticism== Two objections to rational egoism are given by the English philosopher [[Derek Parfit]], who discusses the theory at length in ''[[Reasons and Persons]]'' (1984).<ref>D. Parfit (1984), parts II and III</ref> First, from the rational egoist point of view, it is rational to contribute to a [[pension scheme]] now, even though this is detrimental to one's present interests (which are to spend the money now). But it seems equally reasonable to maximize one's interests now, given that one's reasons are not only relative to him, but to him as he is now (and not his future self, who is argued to be a "different" person). Parfit also argues that since the connections between the present mental state and the mental state of one's future self may decrease, it is not plausible to claim that one should be indifferent between one's present and future self.
The "[[Gene-centered view of evolution|selfish gene]]" model of [[evolution]] suggests that human (and animal) behaviors that seem altruistic are actually selfish, if viewed from the perspective of [[Gene|genes]]/[[Phenotype|phenotypes]]. People help each other "selflessly" because copies of their own genes also exist in others, so behaviors that help the genes survive are [[Natural selection|selected]] for, with the altruistic drive [[Kin selection|decreasing with genetic distance]].
